title: Quickly test linear regression assumptions
text: recently discovered wonderful package easily checking linear regression assumptions via diagnostic plots: check_model() function performance package. Let’s make quick demonstration package first.  Wonderful! efficient. However, sometimes, different reasons, someone might want check assumptions objective test. Testing assumption one one kind time-consuming, made convenience function accelerate process. Just warning jumping objective assumption tests. Note tests generally recommended! large sample size, objective assumption tests -sensitive deviations expected values, small sample size, objective assumption tests -powered detect real, existing deviations. can also mask visual patterns reflected single number. thus recommended use visual assessment diagnostic plots instead (e.g., see Kozak & Piepho, 2018; Schucany & Ng, 2006). quick accessible argument tests normality specifically, see source.
code: # Load necessary libraries library(performance) library(see) # Note: if you haven't installed the packages above, you'll need to install them first by using: # install.packages("performance") and install.packages("see")  # Create a regression model (using data available in R by default) model <- lm(mpg ~ wt * cyl + gear, data = mtcars) # Check model assumptions check_model(model)

title: Quickly test linear regression assumptions
text: Load rempsyc package: Note: haven’t installed package yet, need install via following command: devtools::install_github("rempsyc/rempsyc"). Package devtools necessary command. haven’t installed devtools yet, install via install.packages("devtools"). raw output doesn’t look nice console column names long, look good viewer exported word processing software column names get wrapped. can try Rstudio following command:  Model... Normality (Shapiro-Wilk)... Homoscedasticity (Breusch-Pagan)... Autocorrelation residuals (Durbin-Watson)... Diagnostic... mpg ~ wt * cyl + gear .615 .054 .525 0 function particularly useful testing several models simultaneously makes nice table results. Let’s make short demonstration . Use Viewer better results  alternatively nice_table() function Model... Normality (Shapiro-Wilk)... Homoscedasticity (Breusch-Pagan)... Autocorrelation residuals (Durbin-Watson)... Diagnostic... cyl ~ mpg .361 .282 .460 0 disp ~ mpg .506 .831 .077 0 hp ~ mpg .004 .351 .198 1 drat ~ mpg .939 .887 .505 0 wt ~ mpg .020 .270 .002 2 qsec ~ mpg .427 .944 .011 1 vs ~ mpg .142 .568 .238 0 ~ mpg .074 .650 < .001 1 gear ~ mpg .001 .528 < .001 2 carb ~ mpg .008 .362 .003 2
code: library(rempsyc) View(nice_assumptions(model)) nice_table(nice_assumptions(model), col.format.p = 2:4) ## Interpretation: (p) values < .05 imply assumptions are not respected. Diagnostic is how many assumptions are not respected for a given model or variable. # Define our dependent variables DV <- names(mtcars[-1]) # Make list of all formulas formulas <- paste(DV, "~ mpg") # Make list of all models models.list <- sapply(X = formulas, FUN = lm, data = mtcars, simplify = FALSE, USE.NAMES = TRUE) # Make diagnostic table assumptions.table <- do.call("rbind", lapply(models.list, nice_assumptions, interpretation = FALSE)) View(assumptions.table) nice_table(assumptions.table, col.format.p = 2:4)

title: Quickly test linear regression assumptions
text: categorical predictors (e.g., groups), suggested check assumptions directly raw data rather residuals (source). case, one can make qqplots different groups first check normality assumption.

title: Quickly test linear regression assumptions
text: Generally speaking, long dots lie within confidence band, good data distribute normally.
code: nice_qq(data = iris,         variable = "Sepal.Length",         group = "Species")

title: Quickly test linear regression assumptions
text: Change (reorder) colours, x-axis title y-axis title, names groups, grid lines, add p-value Shapiro-Wilk (wish ).  p > .05 suggests data normally distributed (according Shapiro-Wilk test). Inversely, p < .05 suggests data normally distributed. Keep mind however several known problems objective tests, visual assessment recommended. Nonetheless, beginners, can sometimes useful (rather, reassuring) able pair visual assessment tests values.
code: nice_qq(data = iris,         variable = "Sepal.Length",         group = "Species",         colours = c("#00BA38", "#619CFF", "#F8766D"),         groups.labels = c("(a) Setosa", "(b) Versicolor", "(c) Virginica"),         grid = FALSE,         shapiro = TRUE,         title = NULL)

title: Quickly test linear regression assumptions
text: people think density distributions less useful qqplots, sometimes, people still like look distributions, made another function .

title: Quickly test linear regression assumptions
text: Pro tip: Save density plots narrower width better-looking results.
code: nice_density(data = iris,              variable = "Sepal.Length",              group = "Species")

title: Quickly test linear regression assumptions
text: Change (reorder) colours, x-axis title y-axis title, names groups, grid lines, add p-value Shapiro-Wilk (wish ).
code: nice_density(data = iris,              variable = "Sepal.Length",              group = "Species",              colours = c("#00BA38", "#619CFF", "#F8766D"),              xtitle = "Sepal Length",              ytitle = "Density (vs. Normal Distribution)",              groups.labels = c("(a) Setosa", "(b) Versicolor", "(c) Virginica"),              grid = FALSE,              shapiro = TRUE,              histogram = TRUE,              title = "Density (Sepal Length)")

code: nice_normality(data = iris,                variable = "Sepal.Length",                group = "Species",                shapiro = TRUE,                histogram = TRUE,                title = "Density (Sepal Length)")

title: Planned Contrasts Analyses (Group Comparisons)
text: post, document conduct planned contrasts analyses test whether experimental groups differ . Planned contrasts similar t tests, provide power several groups: Statistical power lower standard t test compared planned contrast version two reasons: ) sample size smaller t test, cases two groups selected; b) planned contrast error term smaller standard t test based cases (source) first demonstrate simple example conducting analysis, exporting table results Microsoft Word, producing figure. demonstrating single variable, look full workflow, .e., can automatize process several variables simultaneously.

title: Planned Contrasts Analyses (Group Comparisons)
text: minimal example, use iris dataset, installed R default.

title: Planned Contrasts Analyses (Group Comparisons)
text: Load rempsyc package: Note: haven’t installed package yet, need install via following command: devtools::install_github("rempsyc/rempsyc"). Package devtools necessary command. haven’t installed devtools yet, install via install.packages("devtools"). Let’s test function existing data give us ‘robust’ version Cohen’s d (.e., robust deviations parametric assumptions). also provide us bootstrapped 95% confidence intervals effect size.
code: library(rempsyc) table.stats <- nice_contrasts(response = "Sepal.Length",                               group = "Species",                               data = iris) table.stats ##   Dependent Variable             Comparison  df          t            p ## 1       Sepal.Length     setosa - virginica 147 -15.365506 2.214821e-32 ## 2       Sepal.Length versicolor - virginica 147  -6.332686 2.765638e-09 ## 3       Sepal.Length    setosa - versicolor 147  -9.032819 8.770194e-16 ##          dR  CI_lower   CI_upper ## 1 -2.929466 -3.548201 -2.2526838 ## 2 -1.205879 -1.702488 -0.6861595 ## 3 -1.723587 -2.159221 -1.1558481

title: Planned Contrasts Analyses (Group Comparisons)
text: Dependent Variable Comparison df t p dR 95% CI Sepal.Length setosa - virginica 147 -15.37 < .001 -2.93 [-3.55, -2.25] Sepal.Length versicolor - virginica 147 -6.33 < .001 -1.21 [-1.70, -0.69] Sepal.Length setosa - versicolor 147 -9.03 < .001 -1.72 [-2.16, -1.16] Save table Word
code: (my_table <- nice_table(table.stats)) save_as_docx(my_table, path = "D:/R treasures/contrasts.docx")

title: Planned Contrasts Analyses (Group Comparisons)
text: Let’s save high-resolution/vector version figure PDF (.png format necessary). Congratulations making far! ’ve done ! Z, now know make things work! like integrate broader workflow, read next part!
code: (figure <- nice_violin(group = "Species",                         response = "Sepal.Length",                         data = iris,                        ytitle = "Length of Sepal",                         signif_annotation=c("***", "***", "***"),                        signif_yposition=c(8.7, 7.3, 8.2),                        signif_xmin=c("setosa","setosa","versicolor"),                        signif_xmax=c("virginica","versicolor","virginica"))) ggsave('Figure 1.pdf', figure, width=7, height=7, unit='in',         dpi=300, path = "D:/R treasures/")

code: data <- read.csv("https://osf.io/qkmnp//?action=download", header=TRUE) (data$Group <- factor(data$Group, levels = c("Embodied", "Mental", "Control"))) ##  [1] Embodied Embodied Control  Control  Mental   Embodied Control  Control  ##  [9] Control  Embodied Mental   Mental   Control  Control  Mental   Control  ## [17] Mental   Mental   Embodied Embodied Control  Embodied Mental   Control  ## [25] Embodied Embodied Mental   Control  Mental   Embodied Embodied Mental   ## [33] Mental   Mental   Embodied Mental   Embodied Mental   Control  Embodied ## [41] Mental   Mental   Embodied Mental   Mental   Embodied Control  Control  ## [49] Control  Mental   Embodied Control  Embodied Control  Mental   Embodied ## [57] Embodied Embodied Control  Control  Control  Control  Mental   Control  ## [65] Mental   Embodied Embodied Mental   Embodied Control  Control  Mental   ## [73] Mental   Control  Control  Embodied Mental   Control  Embodied Embodied ## [81] Embodied Mental   Control  Control  Embodied Mental   Mental   Mental   ## [89] Embodied Control  ## Levels: Embodied Mental Control library(dplyr) (DV <- data %>% select(QCAEPR:IOS) %>% names) ## [1] "QCAEPR" "IRIPT"  "IRIFS"  "IRIEC"  "IRIPD"  "IOS" table.stats <- nice_contrasts(response = DV,                               group = "Group",                               data = data) table.stats ##    Dependent Variable         Comparison df           t            p ## 1              QCAEPR Embodied - what: Make violin plots comparing groups through nice_violin.
title: Planned Contrasts Analyses (Group Comparisons)
text: make four figures comparisons significant combine one plot. function throw error dataset contains missing data. omit rows missing data now. Make figure panel 1  Make figure panel 2  Make figure panel 3  Make figure panel 4  ’s now time combine four plots one figure! Yeah!  Let’s save high-resolution/vector version figure PDF (.png format necessary).
code: Data <- na.omit(data) (EC <- nice_violin(group = "Group",                    response = "IRIEC",                     data = Data,                    colours = c("#00BA38", "#619CFF", "#F8766D"),                     ytitle = "Empathic Concern (from IRI)",                     signif_annotation = "*",                     signif_yposition = 5.2,                     signif_xmin = 1,                     signif_xmax = 3)) (PD <- nice_violin(group = "Group",                     response = "IRIPD",                     data = Data,                    colours = c("#00BA38", "#619CFF", "#F8766D"),                     ytitle = "Personal Distress (from IRI)",                     signif_annotation = "*",                     signif_yposition = 5,                     signif_xmin = 1,                    signif_xmax = 3)) (PR <- nice_violin(group = "Group",                     response = "QCAEPR",                     data = Data,                    colours = c("#00BA38", "#619CFF", "#F8766D"),                     ytitle = "Peripheral Responsivity (from QCAE)",                     signif_annotation="*",                    signif_yposition=4.2,                    signif_xmin=1,                    signif_xmax=3)) (IOS <- nice_violin(group = "Group",                      response = "IOS",                      data = Data,                     colours = c("#00BA38", "#619CFF", "#F8766D"),                      ytitle = "Self-Other Merging (from IOS)",                      signif_annotation=c("***", "*", "*"),                     signif_yposition=c(8.25, 7.5, 6.75),                     signif_xmin=c(1,1,2),                     signif_xmax=c(3,2,3))) library(ggpubr) (figure <- ggarrange(EC, PD, PR, IOS,                      labels = "AUTO",                      ncol = 2, nrow = 2)) ggsave('Figure 1.pdf', figure, width=14, height=14, unit='in',         dpi=300, path = "D:/R treasures/")

title: Publication-ready moderations with simple slopes in R
text: Let’s first load demo data. data set comes base R (meaning can directly type command R console). Load rempsyc package: Note: haven’t installed package yet, need install via following command: devtools::install_github("rempsyc/rempsyc"). Package devtools necessary command. haven’t installed devtools yet, install via install.packages("devtools"). moderations simple slopes, usually want standardize (least center) variables.
code: head(mtcars) ##                    mpg cyl disp  hp drat    wt  qsec vs am gear carb ## Mazda RX4         21.0   6  160 110 3.90 2.620 16.46  0  1    4    4 ## Mazda RX4 Wag     21.0   6  160 110 3.90 2.875 17.02  0  1    4    4 ## Datsun 710        22.8   4  108  93 3.85 2.320 18.61  1  1    4    1 ## Hornet 4 Drive    21.4   6  258 110 3.08 3.215 19.44  1  0    3    1 ## Hornet Sportabout 18.7   8  360 175 3.15 3.440 17.02  0  0    3    2 ## Valiant           18.1   6  225 105 2.76 3.460 20.22  1  0    3    1 library(rempsyc) mtcars2 <- lapply(mtcars, scale) |> as.data.frame()

title: Publication-ready moderations with simple slopes in R
text: want look nice Dependent Variable Predictor df b t p sr2 mpg gear 28 -0.09 -0.80 .431 .00 mpg wt 28 -0.95 -8.60 < .001 .56 mpg gear:wt 28 -0.24 -2.16 .040 .04 Note: sr2 (semi-partial correlation squared, also known delta R-square) allows us quantify unique contribution (proportion variance explained) independent variable dependent variable, variables model. sr2 often considered better indicator practical relevance variable.
code: nice_mod(data = mtcars2,          response = "mpg",          predictor = "gear",          moderator = "wt") -> moderations moderations ##   Dependent Variable Predictor df           b          t            p ## 1                mpg      gear 28 -0.08718042 -0.7982999 4.314156e-01 ## 2                mpg        wt 28 -0.94959988 -8.6037724 2.383144e-09 ## 3                mpg   gear:wt 28 -0.23559962 -2.1551077 3.989970e-02 ##           sr2 ## 1 0.004805465 ## 2 0.558188818 ## 3 0.035022025 (my_table <- nice_table(moderations, highlight = TRUE))

Dependent Variable Predictor (+/-1 SD) df b t p sr2 mpg gear (LOW-wt) 28 0.15 1.08 .291 .01 mpg gear (MEAN-wt) 28 -0.09 -0.80 .431 .00 mpg gear (HIGH-wt) 28 -0.32 -1.90 .067 .03 specific case, interaction significant none simple slopes. means although two slopes significantly different , taken individually, slopes aren’t significantly different straight line. neat thing can add many dependent variables want. Model Number Dependent Variable Predictor df b t p sr2 1 mpg gear 28 -0.09 -0.80 .431 .00 1 mpg wt 28 -0.95 -8.60 < .001 .56 1 mpg gear:wt 28 -0.24 -2.16 .040 .04 2 disp gear 28 -0.07 -0.70 .492 .00 2 disp wt 28 0.83 7.67 < .001 .43 2 disp gear:wt 28 -0.09 -0.81 .422 .00 3 hp gear 28 0.42 2.65 .013 .11 3 hp wt 28 0.93 5.75 < .001 .53 3 hp gear:wt 28 0.15 0.96 .346 .01 Model Number Dependent Variable Predictor (+/-1 SD) df b t p sr2 1 mpg gear (LOW-wt) 28 0.15 1.08 .291 .01 1 mpg gear (MEAN-wt) 28 -0.09 -0.80 .431 .00 1 mpg gear (HIGH-wt) 28 -0.32 -1.90 .067 .03 2 disp gear (LOW-wt) 28 0.01 0.09 .926 .00 2 disp gear (MEAN-wt) 28 -0.07 -0.70 .492 .00 2 disp gear (HIGH-wt) 28 -0.16 -0.97 .339 .01 3 hp gear (LOW-wt) 28 0.27 1.34 .190 .03 3 hp gear (MEAN-wt) 28 0.42 2.65 .013 .11 3 hp gear (HIGH-wt) 28 0.58 2.33 .027 .09 Pro tip: nice_mod() nice_slopes() functions take argument, can just copy-paste first change function call save time!
code: nice_slopes(data = mtcars2,             response = "mpg",             predictor = "gear",             moderator = "wt") -> slopes slopes ##   Dependent Variable Predictor (+/-1 SD) df           b          t          p ## 1                mpg       gear (LOW-wt) 28  0.14841920  1.0767040 0.29080233 ## 2                mpg      gear (MEAN-wt) 28 -0.08718042 -0.7982999 0.43141565 ## 3                mpg      gear (HIGH-wt) 28 -0.32278004 -1.9035367 0.06729622 ##           sr2 ## 1 0.008741702 ## 2 0.004805465 ## 3 0.027322839 nice_table(slopes, highlight = TRUE) # Moderations nice_mod(data = mtcars2,          response = c("mpg", "disp", "hp"),          predictor = "gear",          moderator = "wt") |>   nice_table(highlight = TRUE) # Simple slopes nice_slopes(data = mtcars2,             response = c("mpg", "disp", "hp"),             predictor = "gear",             moderator = "wt") |>    nice_table(highlight = TRUE)

title: Publication-ready moderations with simple slopes in R
text: Dependent Variable Predictor (+/-1 SD) df b t p sr2 mpg gear (LOW-wt) 26 0.14 0.89 .383 .00 mpg gear (MEAN-wt) 26 -0.11 -0.88 .388 .00 mpg gear (HIGH-wt) 26 -0.36 -2.25 .033 .03 case, third row significant, means high wt variable (one standard deviation) significantly lower mpg higher gear. can plot traditional way:  Note: haven’t installed package yet, need install via following command: install.packages(interactions). Furthermore, know plot can heavily customized available arguments publication purposes, won’t going details .
code: nice_slopes(data = mtcars2,             response = "mpg",             predictor = "gear",             moderator = "wt",             covariates = c("am", "vs")) |>    nice_table(highlight = TRUE) # First need to define model for plot function mod <- lm(mpg ~ gear * wt + am + vs, data = mtcars2)  # Plot the model library(interactions) interact_plot(mod, pred = "gear", modx = "wt", interval = TRUE)

title: Publication-ready moderations with simple slopes in R
text: Let’s make three-way interaction example. Note simple slopes, now, second moderator needs dichotomic variable (first moderator continuous variable). ’ll reset variable purpose now.
code: mtcars2$am <- mtcars$am

title: Publication-ready moderations with simple slopes in R
code: nice_mod(response = "mpg",          predictor = "gear",          moderator = "disp",          moderator2 = "am",          data = mtcars2) |>    nice_table(highlight = TRUE)

title: Publication-ready moderations with simple slopes in R
text: complicated models supported nice_mod, one can define model traditional way feed nice_lm nice_lm_slopes instead. support multiple lm models well.

title: Publication-ready moderations with simple slopes in R
text: Model Number Dependent Variable Predictor df b t p sr2 1 mpg cyl 27 -0.11 -0.72 .479 .00 1 mpg wt 27 -0.62 -5.70 < .001 .14 1 mpg hp 27 -0.29 -2.40 .023 .02 1 mpg wt:hp 27 0.29 3.23 .003 .04 2 qsec disp 27 -0.43 -1.97 .059 .07 2 qsec drat 27 -0.33 -1.53 .138 .04 2 qsec carb 27 -0.51 -3.32 .003 .20 2 qsec drat:carb 27 -0.23 -1.08 .289 .02 applies simple slopes, time use nice_lm_slopes function. supports multiple lm models well, predictor moderator need models (dependent variable can change).
code: model1 <- lm(mpg ~ cyl + wt * hp, mtcars2) model2 <- lm(qsec ~ disp + drat * carb, mtcars2) my.models <- list(model1, model2) nice_lm(my.models) |>    nice_table(highlight = TRUE)

title: Publication-ready moderations with simple slopes in R
text: Model Number Dependent Variable Predictor (+/-1 SD) df b t p sr2 1 mpg gear (LOW-wt) 28 0.15 1.08 .291 .01 1 mpg gear (MEAN-wt) 28 -0.09 -0.80 .431 .00 1 mpg gear (HIGH-wt) 28 -0.32 -1.90 .067 .03 2 disp gear (LOW-wt) 28 0.01 0.09 .926 .00 2 disp gear (MEAN-wt) 28 -0.07 -0.70 .492 .00 2 disp gear (HIGH-wt) 28 -0.16 -0.97 .339 .01
code: model1 <- lm(mpg ~ gear * wt, mtcars2) model2 <- lm(disp ~ gear * wt, mtcars2) my.models <- list(model1, model2) nice_lm_slopes(my.models, predictor = "gear", moderator = "wt") |>    nice_table(highlight = TRUE)

title: Easy randomization in R
text: ’s easily nice_randomize either within-subject -group! Sure, might just want generate random number n times, hope group gets approximately number participants assigned . , can make sure making “blocks” without replacements. four groups, block four contain group , random order, repeat. Let’s see . Load rempsyc package: Note: haven’t installed package yet, need install via following command: devtools::install_github("rempsyc/rempsyc"). Package devtools necessary command. haven’t installed devtools yet, install via install.packages("devtools").
code: library(rempsyc)

title: Easy randomization in R
text: Basic output default options (3 conditions, 9 participants, -group design): Specify design, number conditions, number participants, names conditions: aware function won’t work -group designs unless sample size multiple number groups (4 groups, sample size can’t 5, 6, 7, can 4, 8, 12, etc., participants). can still try otherwise get error warning message. works “blocks” operations won’t able completed otherwise.
code: nice_randomize() ##   id Condition ## 1  1         a ## 2  2         c ## 3  3         b ## 4  4         a ## 5  5         c ## 6  6         b ## 7  7         b ## 8  8         c ## 9  9         a nice_randomize(design = "between",                 Ncondition = 4,                 n = 8,                 condition.names = c("BP","CX","PZ","ZL")) ##   id Condition ## 1  1        ZL ## 2  2        BP ## 3  3        CX ## 4  4        PZ ## 5  5        BP ## 6  6        CX ## 7  7        ZL ## 8  8        PZ # Warning: sample size needs to be a multiple of your number of groups if using "between"! # FYI: condition names stand for popular antidepressants: # BP = Bupropion, CX = Celexa, PZ = Prozac, ZL = Zoloft.

title: Easy randomization in R
text: Basic output default options (3 conditions 9 participants) within-subject design specified Specify design, number conditions, number participants, names conditions: Note call conditions anything (like , b, c, etc.).
code: nice_randomize(design = "within") ##   id Condition ## 1  1 b - a - c ## 2  2 a - c - b ## 3  3 c - a - b ## 4  4 a - b - c ## 5  5 a - b - c ## 6  6 b - c - a ## 7  7 c - b - a ## 8  8 c - a - b ## 9  9 b - a - c nice_randomize(design = "within",                 Ncondition = 4,                 n = 6,                 condition.names = c("SV","AV","ST","AT")) ##   id         Condition ## 1  1 AT - AV - ST - SV ## 2  2 ST - AV - AT - SV ## 3  3 SV - AT - ST - AV ## 4  4 AT - AV - SV - ST ## 5  5 SV - AV - AT - ST ## 6  6 AT - ST - AV - SV # FYI: condition names stand for forms of multisensory stimulation: # SV = Synchronous Visual, AV = Asynchronous Visual,  # ST = Synchronous Tactile, AT = Asynchronous Tactile.

title: Easy randomization in R
text: nice way make run sheet quickly (regardless design) adding column names advance col.names argument:
code: nice_randomized_subjects <- nice_randomize(design = "within",                                             Ncondition = 4,                                             n = 128,                                            condition.names = c("SV","AV","ST","AT"),                                             col.names = c("id", "Condition", "Date/Time",                                                          "SONA ID", "Age/Gd.", "Handedness",                                                          "Tester", "Notes")) head(nice_randomized_subjects) ##   id         Condition Date/Time SONA ID Age/Gd. Handedness Tester Notes ## 1  1 AV - AT - ST - SV        NA      NA      NA         NA     NA    NA ## 2  2 SV - AT - ST - AV        NA      NA      NA         NA     NA    NA ## 3  3 ST - AT - AV - SV        NA      NA      NA         NA     NA    NA ## 4  4 ST - AV - AT - SV        NA      NA      NA         NA     NA    NA ## 5  5 ST - SV - AT - AV        NA      NA      NA         NA     NA    NA ## 6  6 SV - ST - AT - AV        NA      NA      NA         NA     NA    NA

title: Easy randomization in R
text: Save resulting dataframe nice_table, Word: saving dataframe Word, open Word. Make document horizontal going Layout tab, Page Setup section, clicking “Orientation” button selecting Landscape option.  Select whole table.  Left align table.  Turn preferred width table properties.   Make required formatting arrangements: Home tab, Paragraph section, click Borders button, click Borders.  Next adjust columns width fit page (especially “Notes” column, wider).  necessary, pull table left little square pound Move Table Column button top margin create space (note table selected first).  Double-click header edit add title (e.g., “Study 3 Runsheet”); center bold (suggested font size: 14).  title smaller font (bold; suggested size: 12), add legend conditions (e.g., “SV = Synchronous Visual, AV = Asynchronous Visual, ST = Synchronous Tactile, = Asynchronous Tactile”).  Add page number bottom page going Insert tab, Header & Footer section, click “Page Number” button, selecting “Bottom Page”, Plain Number 3 (bottom right).  Now ‘Save ’ using F12 keyboard key, select save .pdf, ’re done! :)  can now use runsheet , print , send research assistants! Note: might want save word document work lose perhaps reuse future!
code: runsheet <- nice_table(nice_randomized_subjects) save_as_docx(runsheet, path = "runsheet.docx") # Change the path to where you would like to save it. # If you copy-paste your path name, remember to use "R" slashes ('/' rather than '\'). # Also remember to specify the .docx extension of the file.

title: Publication-ready scatter plots in R
text: nice_violin() function, ’s make nice scatter plots easily! Let’s first load demo data. data set comes base R (meaning can directly type command R console).

title: Publication-ready scatter plots in R
text: Load rempsyc package: Note: haven’t installed package yet, need install via following command: devtools::install_github("rempsyc/rempsyc"). Package devtools necessary command. haven’t installed devtools yet, install via install.packages("devtools").  Pro tip: Change .tiff .pdf .eps scalable vector graphics high-resolution submissions scientific journals!
code: library(rempsyc) nice_scatter(data = mtcars,              predictor = "wt",              response = "mpg") ### Save a high-resolution image file to specified directory ggsave('nice_scatterplothere.tiff', width = 7, height = 7, unit = 'in', dpi = 300,        path = "D:/R treasures/") # Change the path to where you would like to save it. # If you copy-paste your path name, remember to use "R" slashes ('/' rather than '\'). # Also remember to specify the .tiff extension of the file.

what: Change x- and y- axis labels
title: Publication-ready scatter plots in R
code: nice_scatter(data = mtcars,              predictor = "wt",              response = "mpg",              ytitle = "Miles/(US) gallon",              xtitle = "Weight (1000 lbs)")

title: Publication-ready scatter plots in R
text: Meaning randomly moved around bit prevent overplotting (two points overlap, thus hiding information).
code: nice_scatter(data = mtcars,              predictor = "wt",              response = "mpg",              has.jitter = TRUE)

what: Change the transparency of the points
title: Publication-ready scatter plots in R
code: nice_scatter(data = mtcars,              predictor = "wt",              response = "mpg",              alpha = 1) # default is 0.7

title: Publication-ready scatter plots in R
code: nice_scatter(data = mtcars,              predictor = "wt",              response = "mpg",              has.points = FALSE,              has.jitter = FALSE)

title: Publication-ready scatter plots in R
code: nice_scatter(data = mtcars,              predictor = "wt",              response = "mpg",              has.confband = TRUE)

what: Add correlation coefficient to plot and p-value

title: Publication-ready scatter plots in R
text: need create FIRST layer just slopes. add transparency group lines except group average emphasize group average (new argument groups.alpha).  Finally ready add SECOND layer just points top previous layer. use standard ggplot syntax .
code: new.Data <- mtcars # This simply copies the 'mtcars' dataset new.Data$cyl <- "Average" # That would be your "Group" variable normally # And this operation fills all cells of that column with the word "Average" to identify our new 'group' XData <- rbind(mtcars,new.Data) # This adds the new "Average" group rows to the original data rows (p <- nice_scatter(data = XData,                    predictor = "wt",                    response = "mpg",                    has.points = FALSE,                    has.legend = TRUE,                    group = "cyl",                    colours = c("black", "#00BA38", "#619CFF", "#F8766D"), # We add colours manually because we want average to be black to stand out                    groups.order = c("Average","4","6","8"), # We do this to have average on top since it's the most important                    groups.alpha = c(1,0.5,0.5,0.5))) # This adds 50% transparency to all lines except the first one (Average) which is 100% library(ggplot2) p + geom_point(data = mtcars,                size = 2,                 alpha = 0.5,                shape = 16, # We use shape 16 because the default shape 19 sometimes causes problems when exporting to PDF                mapping = aes(x = wt,                               y = mpg,                               colour = factor(cyl),                               fill = factor(cyl)))

title: Publication-ready t-tests in R
text: function makes really easy get t-test results one simple, publication-ready table. Let’s first load demo data. data set comes base R (meaning can directly type command R console). Load rempsyc package: Note: haven’t installed package yet, need install via following command: devtools::install_github("rempsyc/rempsyc"). Package devtools necessary command. haven’t installed devtools yet, install via install.packages("devtools"). Note: function relies base R t.test function, uses Welch t-test per default (see : https://daniellakens.blogspot.com/2015/01/always-use-welchs-t-test-instead-.html). use Student t-test, simply add following argument: var.equal = TRUE. Now best thing function can put dependent variables interest function call output sweet, pre-formatted table convenience. want look nice Dependent Variable t df p d 95% CI mpg -3.77 18.33 .001 -1.48 [-2.27, -0.67] cyl 3.35 25.85 .002 1.21 [0.43, 1.97] disp 4.20 29.26 < .001 1.45 [0.64, 2.23] hp 1.27 18.72 .221 0.49 [-0.23, 1.21] drat -5.65 27.20 < .001 -2.00 [-2.86, -1.12] wt 5.49 29.23 < .001 1.89 [1.03, 2.73] Note: d Cohen’s d, 95% CI confidence interval effect size (Cohen’s d). p p-value, df degrees freedom, t t-value.

title: Publication-ready APA tables: from R to Word in 2 min
text: Load rempsyc package: Note: haven’t installed package yet, need install via following command: devtools::install_github("rempsyc/rempsyc"). Package devtools necessary command. haven’t installed devtools yet, install via install.packages("devtools"). function can used almost dataframe (though allow duplicate column names). ’s simple example using mtcars dataset, comes base R (meaning can try example without downloading anything). Table 1 Motor Trend Car Road Tests mpg cyl disp hp drat wt qsec vs gear carb 21.00 6.00 160.00 110.00 3.90 2.62 16.46 0.00 1.00 4.00 4.00 21.00 6.00 160.00 110.00 3.90 2.88 17.02 0.00 1.00 4.00 4.00 22.80 4.00 108.00 93.00 3.85 2.32 18.61 1.00 1.00 4.00 1.00 Note. data extracted 1974 Motor Trend US magazine.  * p < .05, ** p < .01, *** p < .001

title: Publication-ready APA tables: from R to Word in 2 min
text: dataframe looks like (notice large number decimals): Now can apply function! Term β SE t p 95% CI (Intercept) -0.18 0.09 -2.15 .041 [-0.36, -0.01] cyl -0.11 0.15 -0.72 .479 [-0.42, 0.20] wt -0.62 0.11 -5.70 < .001 [-0.85, -0.40] hp -0.29 0.12 -2.40 .023 [-0.53, -0.04] wt:hp 0.29 0.09 3.23 .003 [0.11, 0.47] Next, can save flextable object, can later edit, view, export another software (e.g., Microsoft Word).
code: # Standardize variables to get standardized coefficients mtcars.std <- lapply(mtcars, scale) # Create a simple linear model model <- lm(mpg ~ cyl + wt * hp, mtcars.std) # Gather summary statistics stats.table <- as.data.frame(summary(model)$coefficients) # Get the confidence interval (CI) of the regression coefficient CI <- confint(model) # Add a row to join the variables names and CI to the stats stats.table <- cbind(row.names(stats.table), stats.table, CI) # Rename the columns appropriately names(stats.table) <- c("Term", "B", "SE", "t", "p", "CI_lower", "CI_upper") stats.table ##                    Term          B         SE          t            p ## (Intercept) (Intercept) -0.1835269 0.08532112 -2.1510135 4.058431e-02 ## cyl                 cyl -0.1082286 0.15071576 -0.7180977 4.788652e-01 ## wt                   wt -0.6230206 0.10927573 -5.7013627 4.663587e-06 ## hp                   hp -0.2874898 0.11955935 -2.4045781 2.331865e-02 ## wt:hp             wt:hp  0.2875867 0.08895462  3.2329593 3.221753e-03 ##               CI_lower     CI_upper ## (Intercept) -0.3585914 -0.008462403 ## cyl         -0.4174718  0.201014550 ## wt          -0.8472358 -0.398805290 ## hp          -0.5328053 -0.042174267 ## wt:hp        0.1050669  0.470106453 nice_table(stats.table) my_table <- nice_table(stats.table)

title: Publication-ready APA tables: from R to Word in 2 min
text: Notice provide CI_lower CI_upper column names, automatically properly format confidence interval column remove lower upper bound columns. can also see automatically formats df, b, t, p values italic. also correctly rounded row, formatted p values < .001 stripped leading zeros (correlations r, R2, sr2). Note: order work automatically, columns must named correctly. Currently function make following conversions: p, t, SE, SD, M, W, N, n, z, F, b, r, df italic; R2 sr2 italic squared, dR italic R subscript, np2 italic η subscript-p squared, ges italic η subscript-G squared, B β. seeing symbol ? Contact ’ll add ! Let’s test simply changing dataframe names exercise. dR N M SD W ηp2 ηG2 z r R2 sr2 21.00 6 160.00 110.00 3.90 2.62 16.46 0 1.0 .40 .40 21.00 6 160.00 110.00 3.90 2.88 17.02 0 1.0 .40 .40 22.80 4 108.00 93.00 3.85 2.32 18.61 1 1.0 .40 .10

title: Publication-ready APA tables: from R to Word in 2 min
text: Often, one need tweak table particular situation. fear. function outputs flextable object, can ‘easily’ edited via regular flextable functions. intro flextable functions, see: https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/flextable/vignettes/overview.html. basic formatting example provided flextable package: Model Term Standardized Beta SE t p-value 95% CI (Intercept) -0.18 0.09 -2.15 .041 [-0.36, -0.01] cyl -0.11 0.15 -0.72 .479 [-0.42, 0.20] wt -0.62 0.11 -5.70 < .001 [-0.85, -0.40] hp -0.29 0.12 -2.40 .023 [-0.53, -0.04] wt:hp 0.29 0.09 3.23 .003 [0.11, 0.47]
code: library(dplyr) library(flextable) my_table %>%   italic(j = 1, part = "body") %>%   bg(bg = "gray", part = "header") %>%   color(color = "blue", part = "header") %>%   color(~ t > -3.5, ~ t + SE, color = "red") %>%   bold(~ t > -3.5, ~ t + p, bold = TRUE) %>%   set_header_labels(Term = "Model Term",                     B   = "Standardized Beta",                     p = "p-value")

Variable T1.setosa.M T1.setosa.SD T1.versicolor.M T1.versicolor.SD T1.virginica.M T1.virginica.SD T2.setosa.M T2.setosa.SD T2.versicolor.M T2.versicolor.SD T2.virginica.M T2.virginica.SD Sepal.Length 5.01 0.35 5.94 0.52 6.59 0.64 6.01 0.35 6.94 0.52 7.59 0.64 Sepal.Width 3.43 0.38 2.77 0.31 2.97 0.32 4.43 0.38 3.77 0.31 3.97 0.32 Petal.Length 1.46 0.17 4.26 0.47 5.55 0.55 2.46 0.17 5.26 0.47 6.55 0.55 far good; ’ve managed tranform data suitable format next step. data right shape (header components separated dots), can apply magic: Variable T1 T2 setosa versicolor virginica setosa versicolor virginica M SD M SD M SD M SD M SD M SD Sepal.Length 5.01 0.35 5.94 0.52 6.59 0.64 6.01 0.35 6.94 0.52 7.59 0.64 Sepal.Width 3.43 0.38 2.77 0.31 2.97 0.32 4.43 0.38 3.77 0.31 3.97 0.32 Petal.Length 1.46 0.17 4.26 0.47 5.55 0.55 2.46 0.17 5.26 0.47 6.55 0.55 find efficient way (data wrangling part), please let know. code: # Setup example dataset data <- cbind(iris[c(5, 1:3)], iris[1:3]+1) names(data)[-1] <- c(paste0("T1.", names(data[2:4])),                      paste0("T2.", names(data[2:4])))  # Get descriptive statistics library(dplyr) data %>%   group_by(Species) %>%    summarize(across(T1.Sepal.Length:T2.Petal.Length,                     list(m = mean, sd = sd),                    .names = "{.col}.{.fn}")) -> descriptive.data  # Rename the columns so we can merge them later names(descriptive.data) <- c("Species", rep(c("T1.M", "T1.SD"), 3),                              rep(c("T2.M", "T2.SD"), 3))  # Extract the data by variable and measurement time T1.disp <- cbind(descriptive.data[1, 2:3],                   descriptive.data[2, 2:3],                   descriptive.data[3, 2:3]) T1.hp <- cbind(descriptive.data[1, 4:5],                 descriptive.data[2, 4:5],                 descriptive.data[3, 4:5]) T1.drat <- cbind(descriptive.data[1, 6:7],                   descriptive.data[2, 6:7],                   descriptive.data[3, 6:7]) T2.disp <- cbind(descriptive.data[1, 8:9],                  descriptive.data[2, 8:9],                   descriptive.data[3, 8:9]) T2.hp <- cbind(descriptive.data[1, 10:11],                 descriptive.data[2, 10:11],                 descriptive.data[3, 10:11]) T2.drat <- cbind(descriptive.data[1, 12:13],                   descriptive.data[2, 12:13],                   descriptive.data[3, 12:13])  # Combine Time 1 with Time 2 T1 <- rbind(T1.disp, T1.hp, T1.drat) T2 <- rbind(T2.disp, T2.hp, T2.drat) wide.data <- cbind(Variable = names(iris[1:3]), T1, T2)  # Rename variables to avoid duplicate names not allowed names(wide.data)[-1] <- paste0(   rep(c("T1.", "T2."), each = 6),    rep(descriptive.data$Species, times = 2, each = 2),   paste0(c(".M", ".SD")))  # Make preliminary nice_table nice_table(wide.data) nice_table(wide.data, separate.header = TRUE, italics = seq(wide.data))

title: Publication-ready violin plots in R
text: happened lots plots slight variations, made function make life easier. function, particular, serves compare 2 experimental groups (although still plot 1 group). use violin plots instead bar plots provide information space (precisely, distribution density/frequency responses, allows visually estimate normality, skewness, kurtosis). Let’s first load demo data. data set comes base R (meaning can directly type command R console). Load rempsyc package: Note: haven’t installed package yet, need install via following command: devtools::install_github("rempsyc/rempsyc"). Package devtools necessary command. haven’t installed devtools yet, install via install.packages("devtools").
code: data("ToothGrowth") head(ToothGrowth) ##    len supp dose ## 1  4.2   VC  0.5 ## 2 11.5   VC  0.5 ## 3  7.3   VC  0.5 ## 4  5.8   VC  0.5 ## 5  6.4   VC  0.5 ## 6 10.0   VC  0.5 library(rempsyc) nice_violin(data = ToothGrowth,             group = "dose",             response = "len") Dots  = Means Error bars = 95% bootstrapped confidence Intervals (2000 replications) Width = Distribution Density (Frequency)

title: Publication-ready violin plots in R
text: cool gives 95% bootstrapped confidence interval (2000 bootstraps), shown error bars. Bootstrapping non-parametric technique, meaning need respect classical parametric assumptions (normality, homoscedasticity, etc.). case ’s just nice alternative way look data. Note: bootstrapping requires number bootstraps equal higher number observations (rows). people sometimes work big datasets, ’ve added option specify specific number bootstraps option bootstraps = 2000 (change default desired value). ’ve recently work large data set (7 million observations), impractical 7 million bootstraps (, long operation), also added option turn bootstrapping completely just use regular confidence interval instead; just add boot = FALSE one argument. Pro tip: Change .tiff .pdf .eps scalable vector graphics high-resolution submissions scientific journals!
code: ### Save a high-resolution image file to specified directory ggsave('nice_violinplothere.tiff', width = 7, height = 7, unit = 'in', dpi = 300,        path = "D:/R treasures/") # Change the path to where you would like to save it. # If you copy-paste your path name, remember to use "R" slashes ('/' rather than '\'). # Also remember to specify the .tiff extension of the file.

what: Special situation: Add other plot elements
title: Publication-ready violin plots in R
text: good thing function outputs ggplot object, can continue use build plot customize . instance, recently wanted add mean sample size annotations group (group sample sizes ranging 100 35,000, important know groups representative). demonstration, let’s just build multiple-groups plot earlier. simply added conventional ggplot code plot object. (first compute statistics going using:)
code: # Create our group variable: ToothGrowth$groups <- factor(sample(1:6,60, replace=T))  # Make the plot and save it to object "p" p <- nice_violin(data = ToothGrowth,                  group = "groups",                  response = "len",                  border.size = 1) # Compute basic statistics and save to object library(psych) # Install the psych package if you don't already have it statsSummary <- describeBy(x = ToothGrowth$len, group = ToothGrowth$groups, mat = TRUE)  # Add our annotations! (Warning: a bit more complicated code ahead!) ##+ fig.width=8 library(ggplot2) p + annotate(geom="text", # First annotation adds the average              x=1:length(levels(ToothGrowth$groups)), # Specifies annotations is for all groups/x-axis ticks              y=statsSummary$mean+2, # Puts mean at mean value on the y-axis (adds 2)              label=paste0("m=", round(statsSummary$mean,2))) + # That prints the mean on the plot   annotate(geom="text", # (Second annotation adds the sample size)            x=1:length(levels(ToothGrowth$groups)),            y=statsSummary$mean-2, # Puts sample size at mean value on the y-axis (substracts 2)            label=paste0("n=", round(statsSummary$n,2))) # That prints the sample size on the plot

title: Convenience Functions for Psychology
text: R package convenience functions make workflow faster easier. Easily customizable plots (via ggplot2), nice APA tables exportable Word (via flextable), easily run statistical tests check assumptions, automatize various tasks. Mostly geared researchers psychological sciences. package still active development. Feel free open issue ask help, report bug, request feature. Release notes Development objectives (-list)

title: Convenience Functions for Psychology
text: Easily compute t-test analyses, effect sizes, format publication-ready format. Supports multiple dependent variables . 95% confidence interval effect size (Cohen’s d).  Full tutorial: https://rempsyc.remi-theriault.com/articles/t-test
code: library(rempsyc)  nice_t_test(data = mtcars,             response = c("mpg", "disp", "drat", "wt"),             group = "am") -> t.tests #> Using Welch t-test (base R's default; cf. https://doi.org/10.5334/irsp.82). #> For the Student t-test, use `var.equal = TRUE`.  #>   #>  t.tests #>   Dependent Variable         t       df              p         d   CI_lower #> 1                mpg -3.767123 18.33225 0.001373638333 -1.477947 -2.2659731 #> 2               disp  4.197727 29.25845 0.000230041299  1.445221  0.6417834 #> 3               drat -5.646088 27.19780 0.000005266742 -2.003084 -2.8592770 #> 4                 wt  5.493905 29.23352 0.000006272020  1.892406  1.0300224 #>     CI_upper #> 1 -0.6705686 #> 2  2.2295592 #> 3 -1.1245498 #> 4  2.7329218  # Format t-test results t_table <- nice_table(t.tests) t_table # Save to word save_as_docx(t_table, path = "D:/R treasures/t_tests.docx")

title: Convenience Functions for Psychology
text: Easily compute regression planned contrast analyses (pairwise comparisons similar t-tests powerful 2 groups), format publication-ready format. Supports multiple dependent variables (supports three groups moment). particular case, confidence intervals bootstraped around Robust Cohen’s d.  Full tutorial: https://rempsyc.remi-theriault.com/articles/contrasts

title: Convenience Functions for Psychology
text: Easily compute moderation analyses, effect sizes, format publication-ready format. Supports multiple dependent variables covariates .  Full tutorial: https://rempsyc.remi-theriault.com/articles/moderation
code: nice_mod(data = mtcars,          response = c("mpg", "disp"),          predictor = "gear",          moderator = "wt") -> moderations moderations #>   Model Number Dependent Variable Predictor df          b          t          p #> 1            1                mpg      gear 28   5.615951  1.9437108 0.06204275 #> 2            1                mpg        wt 28   1.403861  0.4301493 0.67037970 #> 3            1                mpg   gear:wt 28  -1.966931 -2.1551077 0.03989970 #> 4            2               disp      gear 28  35.797623  0.6121820 0.54535707 #> 5            2               disp        wt 28 160.930043  2.4364098 0.02144867 #> 6            2               disp   gear:wt 28 -15.037022 -0.8140664 0.42247646 #>           sr2 #> 1 0.028488305 #> 2 0.001395217 #> 3 0.035022025 #> 4 0.002737218 #> 5 0.043355972 #> 6 0.004840251  # Format moderation results nice_table(moderations, highlight = TRUE)

title: Convenience Functions for Psychology
text: Easily compute simple slopes moderation analysis, effect sizes, format publication-ready format. Supports multiple dependent variables covariates .  Full tutorial: https://rempsyc.remi-theriault.com/articles/moderation
code: nice_slopes(data = mtcars,             response = c("mpg", "disp"),             predictor = "gear",             moderator = "wt") -> simple.slopes simple.slopes #>   Model Number Dependent Variable Predictor (+/-1 SD) df         b         t #> 1            1                mpg       gear (LOW-wt) 28  7.540509 2.0106560 #> 2            1                mpg      gear (MEAN-wt) 28  5.615951 1.9437108 #> 3            1                mpg      gear (HIGH-wt) 28  3.691393 1.7955678 #> 4            2               disp       gear (LOW-wt) 28 50.510710 0.6654856 #> 5            2               disp      gear (MEAN-wt) 28 35.797623 0.6121820 #> 6            2               disp      gear (HIGH-wt) 28 21.084536 0.5067498 #>            p         sr2 #> 1 0.05408136 0.030484485 #> 2 0.06204275 0.028488305 #> 3 0.08336403 0.024311231 #> 4 0.51118526 0.003234637 #> 5 0.54535707 0.002737218 #> 6 0.61629796 0.001875579  # Format simple slopes results1 nice_table(simple.slopes)

title: Convenience Functions for Psychology
text: complicated models supported nice_slopes, one can define model traditional way feed nice_lm_slopes instead. Supports multiple lm models well, predictor moderator need models (dependent variable can change). Full tutorial: https://rempsyc.remi-theriault.com/articles/moderation
code: model1 <- lm(mpg ~ gear * wt, mtcars) model2 <- lm(disp ~ gear * wt, mtcars) my.models <- list(model1, model2) nice_lm_slopes(my.models, predictor = "gear", moderator = "wt") #>   Model Number Dependent Variable Predictor (+/-1 SD) df         b         t #> 1            1                mpg       gear (LOW-wt) 28  7.540509 2.0106560 #> 2            1                mpg      gear (MEAN-wt) 28  5.615951 1.9437108 #> 3            1                mpg      gear (HIGH-wt) 28  3.691393 1.7955678 #> 4            2               disp       gear (LOW-wt) 28 50.510710 0.6654856 #> 5            2               disp      gear (MEAN-wt) 28 35.797623 0.6121820 #> 6            2               disp      gear (HIGH-wt) 28 21.084536 0.5067498 #>            p         sr2 #> 1 0.05408136 0.030484485 #> 2 0.06204275 0.028488305 #> 3 0.08336403 0.024311231 #> 4 0.51118526 0.003234637 #> 5 0.54535707 0.002737218 #> 6 0.61629796 0.001875579

title: Convenience Functions for Psychology
text: Nicely reports NA values according existing guidelines (.e, reporting absolute percentage item-based missing values, plus scale’s maximum amount missing values given participant). Accordingly, allows specifying list columns representing questionnaire items produce questionnaire-based report missing values.
code: # Create synthetic data frame for the demonstration set.seed(50) df <- data.frame(scale1_Q1 = sample(c(NA, 1:6), replace = TRUE),                  scale1_Q2 = sample(c(NA, 1:6), replace = TRUE),                  scale1_Q3 = sample(c(NA, 1:6), replace = TRUE),                  scale2_Q1 = sample(c(NA, 1:6), replace = TRUE),                  scale2_Q2 = sample(c(NA, 1:6), replace = TRUE),                  scale2_Q3 = sample(c(NA, 1:6), replace = TRUE),                  scale3_Q1 = sample(c(NA, 1:6), replace = TRUE),                  scale3_Q2 = sample(c(NA, 1:6), replace = TRUE),                  scale3_Q3 = sample(c(NA, 1:6), replace = TRUE))  # Then select your scales by name nice_na(df, scales = c("scale1", "scale2", "scale3")) #>                   var items na cells na_percent na_max na_max_percent #> 1 scale1_Q1:scale1_Q3     3  0    21       0.00      0           0.00 #> 2 scale2_Q1:scale2_Q3     3  3    21      14.29      1          33.33 #> 3 scale3_Q1:scale3_Q3     3  2    21       9.52      1          33.33 #> 4               Total     9  5    63       7.94      2          22.22  # Or whole dataframe nice_na(df) #>                   var items na cells na_percent na_max na_max_percent #> 1 scale1_Q1:scale3_Q3     9  5    63       7.94      2          22.22

title: Convenience Functions for Psychology

code: # Reverse score of 5 with a maximum score of 5 nice_reverse(5, 5) #> Note: If your scale minimum score is not '1', please specify it in the 'min' argument #> [1] 1  # Reverse scores with maximum = 4 and minimum = 0 nice_reverse(1:4, 4, min = 0) #> [1] 3 2 1 0  # Reverse scores with maximum = 3 and minimum = -3 nice_reverse(-3:3, 3, min = -3) #> [1]  3  2  1  0 -1 -2 -3

what: Easy export of correlation matrix to Excel — cormatrix_excel2
title: Easy export of correlation matrix to Excel — cormatrix_excel2
text: Easily output correlation matrix export Microsoft Excel, first row column frozen, correlation coefficients colour-coded based effect size (0.0-0.2: small (colour); 0.2-0.4: medium (pink/light blue); 0.4-1.0: large (red/dark blue)), following Cohen's suggestions small (.10), medium (.30), large (.50) correlation sizes. Based correlation openxlsx2 packages. WARNING: function replace cormatrix_excel (original one) soon openxlsx2 available CRAN. meanwhile, experimental subject change. Use care.

title: Easy export of correlation matrix to Excel — cormatrix_excel2
code: cormatrix_excel2(data, filename = "cormatrix", overwrite = TRUE, ...)

title: Easy export of correlation matrix to Excel — cormatrix_excel2
text: data data frame filename Desired filename (path can added hand need specify extension). overwrite Whether allow overwriting previous file. ... Parameters passed correlation package (see ?correlation::correlation)

title: Easy export of correlation matrix to Excel — cormatrix_excel2
text: Adapted @JanMarvin (JanMarvin/openxlsx2#286) original rempsyc::cormatrix_excel

title: Easy export of correlation matrix to Excel — cormatrix_excel2
code: if (FALSE) { # Basic example cormatrix_excel2(mtcars) cormatrix_excel2(iris, p_adjust = "none") cormatrix_excel2(airquality, method = "spearman") }

what: Identify outliers based on 3 MAD — find_mad
title: Identify outliers based on 3 MAD — find_mad
text: Identify outliers based 3 median absolute deviations. See: Leys, C., Ley, C., Klein, O., Bernard, P., & Licata, L. (2013). Detecting outliers: use standard deviation around mean, use absolute deviation around median. Journal Experimental Social Psychology, 49(4), 764–766. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jesp.2013.03.013

title: Easy assumptions checks — nice_assumptions
text: Test linear regression assumptions easily nice summary table.

title: Easy assumptions checks — nice_assumptions
text: model lm object passed function. interpretation Whether display interpretation helper .

title: Easy assumptions checks — nice_assumptions
code: # Create a regression model (using data available in R by default) model <- lm(mpg ~ wt * cyl + gear, data = mtcars) nice_assumptions(model) #> Interpretation: (p) values < .05 imply assumptions are not respected. Diagnostic is how many assumptions are not respected for a given model or variable.  #>  #>                Model... Normality (Shapiro-Wilk)... #> 1 mpg ~ wt * cyl + gear                       0.615 #>   Homoscedasticity (Breusch-Pagan)... #> 1                               0.054 #>   Autocorrelation of residuals (Durbin-Watson)... Diagnostic... #> 1                                           0.525             0  # Multiple dependent variables at once DV <- names(mtcars[-1]) formulas <- paste(DV, "~ mpg") models.list <- lapply(X = formulas, FUN = lm, data = mtcars) assumptions.table <- do.call("rbind", lapply(models.list, nice_assumptions,   interpretation = FALSE )) assumptions.table #>      Model... Normality (Shapiro-Wilk)... Homoscedasticity (Breusch-Pagan)... #> 1   cyl ~ mpg                       0.361                               0.282 #> 2  disp ~ mpg                       0.506                               0.831 #> 3    hp ~ mpg                       0.004                               0.351 #> 4  drat ~ mpg                       0.939                               0.887 #> 5    wt ~ mpg                       0.020                               0.270 #> 6  qsec ~ mpg                       0.427                               0.944 #> 7    vs ~ mpg                       0.142                               0.568 #> 8    am ~ mpg                       0.074                               0.650 #> 9  gear ~ mpg                       0.001                               0.528 #> 10 carb ~ mpg                       0.008                               0.362 #>    Autocorrelation of residuals (Durbin-Watson)... Diagnostic... #> 1                                            0.460             0 #> 2                                            0.077             0 #> 3                                            0.198             1 #> 4                                            0.505             0 #> 5                                            0.002             2 #> 6                                            0.011             1 #> 7                                            0.238             0 #> 8                                            0.000             1 #> 9                                            0.000             2 #> 10                                           0.003             2

code: # Make and format model model <- lm(mpg ~ gear * wt, mtcars) nice_lm_slopes(model, predictor = "gear", moderator = "wt") #>   Dependent Variable Predictor (+/-1 SD) df        b        t          p #> 1                mpg       gear (LOW-wt) 28 7.540509 2.010656 0.05408136 #> 2                mpg      gear (MEAN-wt) 28 5.615951 1.943711 0.06204275 #> 3                mpg      gear (HIGH-wt) 28 3.691393 1.795568 0.08336403 #>          sr2 #> 1 0.03048448 #> 2 0.02848830 #> 3 0.02431123  # Make and format multiple models model2 <- lm(qsec ~ gear * wt, mtcars) my.models <- list(model, model2) nice_lm_slopes(my.models, predictor = "gear", moderator = "wt") #>   Model Number Dependent Variable Predictor (+/-1 SD) df         b          t #> 1            1                mpg       gear (LOW-wt) 28  7.540509  2.0106560 #> 2            1                mpg      gear (MEAN-wt) 28  5.615951  1.9437108 #> 3            1                mpg      gear (HIGH-wt) 28  3.691393  1.7955678 #> 4            2               qsec       gear (LOW-wt) 28 -1.933515 -0.8847558 #> 5            2               qsec      gear (MEAN-wt) 28 -1.742853 -1.0351610 #> 6            2               qsec      gear (HIGH-wt) 28 -1.552191 -1.2956736 #>            p        sr2 #> 1 0.05408136 0.03048448 #> 2 0.06204275 0.02848830 #> 3 0.08336403 0.02431123 #> 4 0.38382325 0.02280057 #> 5 0.30945179 0.03121151 #> 6 0.20566798 0.04889790

what: Report missing values according to guidelines — nice_na
title: Report missing values according to guidelines — nice_na
text: Nicely reports NA values according existing guidelines. function reports absolute percentage values specified column lists. authors recommend reporting item-level missing item per scale, well participant’s maximum number missing items scale. example, Parent (2013) writes: recommend authors () state tolerance level missing data scale subscale (e.g., “calculated means subscales participants gave least 75% complete data”) (b) report individual missingness rates scale per data point (.e., number missing values data points scale participants) maximum participant (e.g., “Attachment Anxiety, total 4 missing data points 100 observed, participant missing single data point”). See: Parent, M. C. (2013). Handling item-level missing data: Simpler just good. Counseling Psychologist, 41(4), 568-600. https://doi.org/10.1177%2F0011000012445176

title: Report missing values according to guidelines — nice_na
code: nice_na(data, vars, scales)

title: Report missing values according to guidelines — nice_na
text: data data frame. vars Variable (lists variables) check NAs. scales scale names check NAs (single character string).

title: Report missing values according to guidelines — nice_na
code: # Use whole data frame nice_na(airquality) #>         var items na cells na_percent na_max na_max_percent #> 1 Ozone:Day     6 44   918       4.79      2          33.33  # Use selected columns explicitly nice_na(airquality,   vars = list(     c("Ozone", "Solar.R", "Wind"),     c("Temp", "Month", "Day")   ) ) #>          var items na cells na_percent na_max na_max_percent #> 1 Ozone:Wind     3 44   459       9.59      2          66.67 #> 2   Temp:Day     3  0   459       0.00      0           0.00 #> 3      Total     6 44   918       4.79      2          33.33  # If the questionnaire items start with the same name, e.g., set.seed(15) fun <- function() {   sample(c(NA, 1:10), replace = TRUE) } df <- data.frame(   scale1_Q1 = fun(), scale1_Q2 = fun(), scale1_Q3 = fun(),   scale2_Q1 = fun(), scale2_Q2 = fun(), scale2_Q3 = fun(),   scale3_Q1 = fun(), scale3_Q2 = fun(), scale3_Q3 = fun() ) # One can list the scale names directly: nice_na(df, scales = c("scale1", "scale2", "scale3")) #>                   var items na cells na_percent na_max na_max_percent #> 1 scale1_Q1:scale1_Q3     3  2    33       6.06      1          33.33 #> 2 scale2_Q1:scale2_Q3     3  8    33      24.24      2          66.67 #> 3 scale3_Q1:scale3_Q3     3  1    33       3.03      1          33.33 #> 4               Total     9 11    99      11.11      3          33.33

code: # Specify design, number of conditions, number of # participants, and names of conditions: nice_randomize(   design = "between", Ncondition = 4, n = 8,   condition.names = c("BP", "CX", "PZ", "ZL") ) #>   id Condition #> 1  1        PZ #> 2  2        CX #> 3  3        BP #> 4  4        ZL #> 5  5        ZL #> 6  6        BP #> 7  7        PZ #> 8  8        CX  # Within-Group Design nice_randomize(   design = "within", Ncondition = 4, n = 6,   condition.names = c("SV", "AV", "ST", "AT") ) #>   id         Condition #> 1  1 SV - ST - AV - AT #> 2  2 AT - SV - ST - AV #> 3  3 AV - AT - SV - ST #> 4  4 SV - AT - AV - ST #> 5  5 ST - AV - AT - SV #> 6  6 AV - AT - ST - SV  # Make a quick runsheet randomized <- nice_randomize(   design = "within", Ncondition = 4, n = 128,   condition.names = c("SV", "AV", "ST", "AT"),   col.names = c(     "id", "Condition", "Date/Time",     "SONA ID", "Age/Gd.", "Handedness",     "Tester", "Notes"   ) ) head(randomized) #>   id         Condition Date/Time SONA ID Age/Gd. Handedness Tester Notes #> 1  1 SV - ST - AT - AV        NA      NA      NA         NA     NA    NA #> 2  2 SV - ST - AV - AT        NA      NA      NA         NA     NA    NA #> 3  3 AT - ST - AV - SV        NA      NA      NA         NA     NA    NA #> 4  4 AT - ST - SV - AV        NA      NA      NA         NA     NA    NA #> 5  5 SV - AV - AT - ST        NA      NA      NA         NA     NA    NA #> 6  6 AV - AT - SV - ST        NA      NA      NA         NA     NA    NA

Whether display legend . legend.title desired legend title. group group plot variable colours Desired colours plot, desired. groups.order Specifies desired display order groups. groups.labels Changes groups names (labels). Note: applies changing order level. groups.alpha manually specified transparency desired groups slopes. Use plotting groups separately. .r Whether display correlation coefficient, r-value. r.x x-axis coordinates r-value. r.y y-axis coordinates r-value. .p Whether display p-value. p.x x-axis coordinates p-value. p.y y-axis coordinates p-value.

code: # Make the basic plot nice_scatter(   data = mtcars,   predictor = "wt",   response = "mpg" )   if (FALSE) { # Save a high-resolution image file to specified directory ggsave("nicescatterplothere.pdf",   width = 7, height = 7, unit = "in",   dpi = 300, path = "/" ) # change for your own desired path }  # Change x- and y- axis labels nice_scatter(   data = mtcars,   predictor = "wt",   response = "mpg",   ytitle = "Miles/(US) gallon",   xtitle = "Weight (1000 lbs)" )   # Have points "jittered" nice_scatter(   data = mtcars,   predictor = "wt",   response = "mpg",   has.jitter = TRUE )   # Change the transparency of the points nice_scatter(   data = mtcars,   predictor = "wt",   response = "mpg",   alpha = 1 )   # Remove points nice_scatter(   data = mtcars,   predictor = "wt",   response = "mpg",   has.points = FALSE,   has.jitter = FALSE )   # Add confidence band nice_scatter(   data = mtcars,   predictor = "wt",   response = "mpg",   has.confband = TRUE )   # Set x- and y- scales manually nice_scatter(   data = mtcars,   predictor = "wt",   response = "mpg",   xmin = 1,   xmax = 6,   xby = 1,   ymin = 10,   ymax = 35,   yby = 5 ) #> Warning: Removed 7 row(s) containing missing values (geom_path).   # Change plot colour nice_scatter(   data = mtcars,   predictor = "wt",   response = "mpg",   colours = "blueviolet" )   # Add correlation coefficient to plot and p-value nice_scatter(   data = mtcars,   predictor = "wt",   response = "mpg",   has.r = TRUE,   has.p = TRUE )   # Change location of correlation coefficient or p-value nice_scatter(   data = mtcars,   predictor = "wt",   response = "mpg",   has.r = TRUE,   r.x = 4,   r.y = 25,   has.p = TRUE,   p.x = 5,   p.y = 20 )   # Plot by group nice_scatter(   data = mtcars,   predictor = "wt",   response = "mpg",   group = "cyl" )   # Use full range on the slope/confidence band nice_scatter(   data = mtcars,   predictor = "wt",   response = "mpg",   group = "cyl",   has.fullrange = TRUE )   # Remove lines nice_scatter(   data = mtcars,   predictor = "wt",   response = "mpg",   group = "cyl",   has.line = FALSE )   # Add a legend nice_scatter(   data = mtcars,   predictor = "wt",   response = "mpg",   group = "cyl",   has.legend = TRUE )   # Change order of labels on the legend nice_scatter(   data = mtcars,   predictor = "wt",   response = "mpg",   group = "cyl",   has.legend = TRUE,   groups.order = c(8, 4, 6) )   # Change legend labels nice_scatter(   data = mtcars,   predictor = "wt",   response = "mpg",   group = "cyl",   has.legend = TRUE,   groups.labels = c("Weak", "Average", "Powerful") )  # Warning: This applies after changing order of level  # Add a title to legend nice_scatter(   data = mtcars,   predictor = "wt",   response = "mpg",   group = "cyl",   has.legend = TRUE,   legend.title = "cylinders" )   # Plot by group + manually specify colours nice_scatter(   data = mtcars,   predictor = "wt",   response = "mpg",   group = "cyl",   colours = c("burlywood", "darkgoldenrod", "chocolate") )   # Plot by group + use different line types for each group nice_scatter(   data = mtcars,   predictor = "wt",   response = "mpg",   group = "cyl",   has.linetype = TRUE )   # Plot by group + use different point shapes for each group nice_scatter(   data = mtcars,   predictor = "wt",   response = "mpg",   group = "cyl",   has.shape = TRUE )

title: Easy t-tests — nice_t_test
text: Easily compute t-test analyses, effect sizes, format publication-ready format. 95% confidence interval effect size, Cohen's d, provided effectsize package. function relies base R t.test function, uses Welch t-test per default (see : https://daniellakens.blogspot.com/2015/01/always-use-welchs-t-test-instead-.html). use Student t-test, simply add following argument: var.equal = TRUE.

title: Easy t-tests — nice_t_test
code: nice_t_test(   data,   response,   group = NULL,   correction = "none",   warning = TRUE,   ... )

title: Easy t-tests — nice_t_test
text: data data frame. response dependent variable. group group comparison. correction correction multiple comparison apply, . Default "none" option (now) "bonferroni". warning Whether display Welch test warning . ... arguments passed t.test function (e.g., use Student instead Welch test, change two-tail one-tail, paired-sample t-test instead independent samples).

title: Easy t-tests — nice_t_test
code: # Make the basic table nice_t_test(   data = mtcars,   response = "mpg",   group = "am" ) #> Using Welch t-test (base R's default; cf. https://doi.org/10.5334/irsp.82). #> For the Student t-test, use `var.equal = TRUE`.  #>   #>   #>   Dependent Variable         t       df           p         d  CI_lower #> 1                mpg -3.767123 18.33225 0.001373638 -1.477947 -2.265973 #>     CI_upper #> 1 -0.6705686  # Multiple dependent variables at once nice_t_test(   data = mtcars,   response = names(mtcars)[1:7],   group = "am" ) #> Using Welch t-test (base R's default; cf. https://doi.org/10.5334/irsp.82). #> For the Student t-test, use `var.equal = TRUE`.  #>   #>   #>   Dependent Variable         t       df            p          d   CI_lower #> 1                mpg -3.767123 18.33225 1.373638e-03 -1.4779471 -2.2659731 #> 2                cyl  3.354114 25.85363 2.464713e-03  1.2084550  0.4315896 #> 3               disp  4.197727 29.25845 2.300413e-04  1.4452210  0.6417834 #> 4                 hp  1.266189 18.71541 2.209796e-01  0.4943081 -0.2260466 #> 5               drat -5.646088 27.19780 5.266742e-06 -2.0030843 -2.8592770 #> 6                 wt  5.493905 29.23352 6.272020e-06  1.8924060  1.0300224 #> 7               qsec  1.287845 25.53421 2.093498e-01  0.4656285 -0.2532864 #>     CI_upper #> 1 -0.6705686 #> 2  1.9683146 #> 3  2.2295592 #> 4  1.2066992 #> 5 -1.1245498 #> 6  2.7329218 #> 7  1.1770176  # Can be passed some of the regular arguments # of base `t.test()`  # Student t-test (instead of Welch) nice_t_test(   data = mtcars,   response = "mpg",   group = "am",   var.equal = TRUE ) #> Using Student t-test.  #>   #>   #>   Dependent Variable         t df            p         d  CI_lower   CI_upper #> 1                mpg -4.106127 30 0.0002850207 -1.477947 -2.265973 -0.6705686  # One-sided instead of two-sided nice_t_test(   data = mtcars,   response = "mpg",   group = "am",   alternative = "less" ) #> Using Welch t-test (base R's default; cf. https://doi.org/10.5334/irsp.82). #> For the Student t-test, use `var.equal = TRUE`.  #>   #>   #>   Dependent Variable         t       df            p         d  CI_lower #> 1                mpg -3.767123 18.33225 0.0006868192 -1.477947 -2.265973 #>     CI_upper #> 1 -0.6705686  # One-sample t-test nice_t_test(   data = mtcars,   response = "mpg",   mu = 10 ) #> Using Welch t-test (base R's default; cf. https://doi.org/10.5334/irsp.82). #> For the Student t-test, use `var.equal = TRUE`.  #>   #>  Using one-sample t-test.  #>   #>   #>   Dependent Variable        t df            p        d CI_lower CI_upper #> 1                mpg 9.470995 31 1.154598e-10 1.674251 1.146018 2.244341  # Paired t-test instead of independent samples nice_t_test(   data = ToothGrowth,   response = "len",   group = "supp",   paired = TRUE ) #> Using paired t-test.  #>   #>   #>   Dependent Variable        t df           p         d CI_lower CI_upper #> 1                len 3.302585 29 0.002549842 0.6029668 0.212385  1.00524 # Make sure cases appear in the same order for # both levels of the grouping factor

what: Easily make nice APA tables — nice_table
title: Easily make nice APA tables — nice_table
text: Make nice APA tables easily wrapper around flextable package sensical defaults automatic formatting features.

title: Easily make nice APA tables — nice_table
code: nice_table(   data,   highlight = FALSE,   italics,   col.format.p,   col.format.r,   format.custom,   col.format.custom,   width = 1,   broom = "",   report = "",   short = FALSE,   title,   footnote,   separate.header )

title: Easily make nice APA tables — nice_table
text: data data frame, converted flextable. data frame duplicate column names. highlight Highlight rows statistically significant results? Requires column named "p" containing p-values. Can either accept logical (TRUE/FALSE) numeric value custom critical p-value threshold (e.g., 0.10 0.001). italics columns headers italic? Useful column names italic picked automatically function. Select numerical range, e.g., 1:3. col.format.p Applies p-value formatting columns named "p" (example data frame full p-values, also possible one column named "p"). Select numerical range, e.g., 1:3. col.format.r Applies r-value formatting columns named "r" (example data frame full r-values, also possible one column named "r"). Select numerical range, e.g., 1:3. format.custom Applies custom formatting columns selected via col.format.custom argument. useful one wants custom formatting p- r-values. can also used transform (e.g., multiply) certain values print specific symbol along values instance. col.format.custom columns apply custom function . Select numerical range, e.g., 1:3. width Width table, percentage total width, exported e.g., Word. broom providing tidy table produced broom package, model type use one wants automatic formatting (options "t.test", "lm", "cor.test", "wilcox.test"). report providing object produced report package, model type use one wants automatic formatting (options "t.test", "lm", "cor.test"). short Logical. Whether return abbreviated version tables made report package. title Optional, add table header, desired. footnote Optional, add table footnote (), desired. separate.header Logical, whether separate headers based name delimiters (.e., periods ".").

title: Easily make nice APA tables — nice_table
code: # Make the basic table my_table <- nice_table(mtcars[1:3, ],   title = "Motor Trend Car Road Tests",   footnote = "Note: 1974 Motor Trend US magazine." ) my_table #> a flextable object. #> col_keys: `mpg`, `cyl`, `disp`, `hp`, `drat`, `wt`, `qsec`, `vs`, `am`, `gear`, `carb`  #> header has 2 row(s)  #> body has 3 row(s)  #> original dataset sample:  #>                mpg cyl disp  hp drat    wt  qsec vs am gear carb #> Mazda RX4     21.0   6  160 110 3.90 2.620 16.46  0  1    4    4 #> Mazda RX4 Wag 21.0   6  160 110 3.90 2.875 17.02  0  1    4    4 #> Datsun 710    22.8   4  108  93 3.85 2.320 18.61  1  1    4    1  if (FALSE) { # Save table to word save_as_docx(my_table, path = "nicetablehere.docx") }  # Publication-ready tables mtcars.std <- lapply(mtcars, scale) model <- lm(mpg ~ cyl + wt * hp, mtcars.std) stats.table <- as.data.frame(summary(model)$coefficients) CI <- confint(model) stats.table <- cbind(   row.names(stats.table),   stats.table, CI ) names(stats.table) <- c(   "Term", "B", "SE", "t", "p",   "CI_lower", "CI_upper" ) nice_table(stats.table, highlight = TRUE) #> a flextable object. #> col_keys: `Term`, `B`, `SE`, `t`, `p`, `95% CI`  #> header has 1 row(s)  #> body has 5 row(s)  #> original dataset sample:  #>                    Term          B         SE          t            p #> (Intercept) (Intercept) -0.1835269 0.08532112 -2.1510135 4.058431e-02 #> cyl                 cyl -0.1082286 0.15071576 -0.7180977 4.788652e-01 #> wt                   wt -0.6230206 0.10927573 -5.7013627 4.663587e-06 #> hp                   hp -0.2874898 0.11955935 -2.4045781 2.331865e-02 #> wt:hp             wt:hp  0.2875867 0.08895462  3.2329593 3.221753e-03 #>                     95% CI signif #> (Intercept) [-0.36, -0.01]   TRUE #> cyl          [-0.42, 0.20]  FALSE #> wt          [-0.85, -0.40]   TRUE #> hp          [-0.53, -0.04]   TRUE #> wt:hp         [0.11, 0.47]   TRUE  # Test different column names test <- head(mtcars) names(test) <- c(   "dR", "N", "M", "SD", "b", "np2",   "ges", "p", "r", "R2", "sr2" ) test[, 10:11] <- test[, 10:11] / 10 nice_table(test) #> a flextable object. #> col_keys: `dR`, `N`, `M`, `SD`, `b`, `np2`, `ges`, `p`, `r`, `R2`, `sr2`  #> header has 1 row(s)  #> body has 6 row(s)  #> original dataset sample:  #>                     dR N   M  SD    b   np2   ges p r  R2 sr2 #> Mazda RX4         21.0 6 160 110 3.90 2.620 16.46 0 1 0.4 0.4 #> Mazda RX4 Wag     21.0 6 160 110 3.90 2.875 17.02 0 1 0.4 0.4 #> Datsun 710        22.8 4 108  93 3.85 2.320 18.61 1 1 0.4 0.1 #> Hornet 4 Drive    21.4 6 258 110 3.08 3.215 19.44 1 0 0.3 0.1 #> Hornet Sportabout 18.7 8 360 175 3.15 3.440 17.02 0 0 0.3 0.2  # Custom cell formatting (such as p or r) nice_table(test[8:11], col.format.p = 2:4, highlight = .001) #> a flextable object. #> col_keys: `p`, `r`, `R2`, `sr2`  #> header has 1 row(s)  #> body has 6 row(s)  #> original dataset sample:  #>                   p r  R2 sr2 signif #> Mazda RX4         0 1 0.4 0.4   TRUE #> Mazda RX4 Wag     0 1 0.4 0.4   TRUE #> Datsun 710        1 1 0.4 0.1  FALSE #> Hornet 4 Drive    1 0 0.3 0.1  FALSE #> Hornet Sportabout 0 0 0.3 0.2   TRUE  nice_table(test[8:11], col.format.r = 1:4) #> a flextable object. #> col_keys: `p`, `r`, `R2`, `sr2`  #> header has 1 row(s)  #> body has 6 row(s)  #> original dataset sample:  #>                   p r  R2 sr2 #> Mazda RX4         0 1 0.4 0.4 #> Mazda RX4 Wag     0 1 0.4 0.4 #> Datsun 710        1 1 0.4 0.1 #> Hornet 4 Drive    1 0 0.3 0.1 #> Hornet Sportabout 0 0 0.3 0.2  # Apply custom functions to cells fun <- function(x) {   x + 11.1 } nice_table(test[8:11], col.format.custom = 2:4, format.custom = "fun") #> Error in set_formatter(., r = fun): object 'fun' not found  fun <- function(x) {   paste("x", x) } nice_table(test[8:11], col.format.custom = 2:4, format.custom = "fun") #> Error in set_formatter(., r = fun): object 'fun' not found  # Separate headers based on periods header.data <- structure(list(   Variable = c(     "Sepal.Length",     "Sepal.Width", "Petal.Length"   ), setosa.M = c(     5.01, 3.43,     1.46   ), setosa.SD = c(0.35, 0.38, 0.17), versicolor.M =     c(5.94, 2.77, 4.26), versicolor.SD = c(0.52, 0.31, 0.47) ), row.names = c(NA, -3L), class = "data.frame" ) nice_table(header.data,   separate.header = TRUE,   italics = 2:4 ) #> a flextable object. #> col_keys: `Variable`, `setosa.M`, `setosa.SD`, `versicolor.M`, `versicolor.SD`  #> header has 2 row(s)  #> body has 3 row(s)  #> original dataset sample:  #>       Variable setosa.M setosa.SD versicolor.M versicolor.SD #> 1 Sepal.Length     5.01      0.35         5.94          0.52 #> 2  Sepal.Width     3.43      0.38         2.77          0.31 #> 3 Petal.Length     1.46      0.17         4.26          0.47
